Are you running Ant from the command line or from within a different IDE?
You mention Eclipse, but it isn't clear if you're running from within
Eclipse using the Ant integration.

If you are, and if you're using Eclipse 2.1.x with the Ant built-in
(probably 1.5.4), you may be experiencing this:
http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=17216

We had the same issue. Increasing the memory speeds it up for a bit, but b/c
of the leak, it eventually runs out of memory all the same. We switched to
running Ant from the command line (where the hook works), then to Ant 1.6 in
Eclipse 2.1.2, and then to Eclipse 3M7. All of those fixed this problem
(though Ant 1.6 in E2.1.2 caused some other problems with our build).

I'll add that I'm overjoyed with Eclipse 3M7.

Galen;

----- Original Message ----- 
From: danrabe
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, February 27, 2004 9:16 AM
Subject: [junit] ant junit performance problem


A full run of our test suite using ant takes about 4 minutes using
fork="true". The same test suite run in Intelilj IDEA takes less than
a minute. I figured this was because I had fork="true" on the junit
task, so I changed it to fork="false". The test execution got
marginally slower, and eventually I got an OutOfMemoryError.

Clearly the ant junit task is doing something radically different
than what happens within the context of IDEA. (The fast same-JVM
execution also occurs when using eclipse.) Has anyone else
experienced this? Any clues as to what might be going on?

I'm using JDK 1.4.2_02 on Windows XP.

Thanks,
Dan
